item.dc:creator: Alex Hoyau
item.content:encoded:
The word “website builder” may have multiple meanings but it has evolved today toward something different from the traditional CMS.

Wikipedia’s article about website builders states that

Website builders are tools that typically allow the construction of websites without manual code editing. They fall into two categories:* online proprietary tools provided by web hosting companies. These are typically intended for users to build their private site. Some companies allow the site owner to install alternative tools (commercial or open source) - the more complex of these may also be described as Content Management Systems;* offline software which runs on a computer, creating pages and which can then publish these pages on any host. (These are often considered to be “website design software” rather than “website builders”.)

So it clearly does not include Wordpress, Joomla and the members of the huge CM family, which are usually free software and requires quite a bit of coding in order to do design but are great tools to edit lots of content (hence the name, Content Management Software).

It does include the great but declining familly of installed - sometime called heavy, desktop applications like BlueGriffon, Adobe Dreamweaver. But today the website builder world is clearly dominated by web proprietary applications like Wix, Squarespace and co. These are “SaaS” and “Freemium” services, which offer a great way to design websites with the mouse and little technical knowledge. They also lock the user in a solution and force them to use their paid and expensive hosting. In some cases, the company monetize the visitors of the websites created with their tool, either sacrificing their privacy or exposing them to ads.

So now let’s be serious, this kind of tool, which puts the internet users in a position where they are the product, need a free and open source alternative:* Facebook has Diaspora* Gmail has Roundcube* Dropbox and Google Drive have OwnCloud* and a French non profit organization is trying to “De-google-ify Internet”, meet Framasoft

So now there is this other French non profit organization Silex Labs, they have developed collaboratively a tool to teach people web design, and it turns out that it is a very good free software alternative to proprietary website builders. I present to you Silex, the free and open source website builder

Silex community makes free and paid templates, and nice websites. They also have an ongoing crowd funding campaign in order to make more of these templates, to produce documentation and also to add a “responsive mode” so that you can customize the mobile version of your website. This is a great way to co-develop a software and make it fit your needs.

Note that Silex does not let you publish your website on its own, you will need a third party to host your website. And the crowd funding campaign is also a way to build an ecosystem of third party tools and services. This is why Indie Hosters offers free hosting or discount on their services to people who will participate to the crowd funding.

Come on and jump in!

item.content:encoded:
J'ai commencé cet article en voulant traduire en Français mon article Website builders are mainstream, mais au final c'est un autre article que j'ai écrit.

Il a été publié sur le site Digital Insider ici.

Le terme de "website builder" n'a pas vraiment d'équivalent fidèle en français. Il se définit comme ceci : les website builders sont des outils qui permettent la construction de sites web sans modification manuelle de code. Ils se répartissent en deux catégories :

  • Des outils propriétaires en ligne fournis par les sociétés d'hébergement web, généralement utilisés pour créer des site personnels.
  • Des logiciels qui s'installent et qui permettent de créer des pages offline pour les publier ensuite avec n'importe quel hébergeur.

Ces derniers sont souvent considérés comme des "logiciels de conception de site" plutôt que comme de purs  "website builders". Les "vrais" website builders sont donc des applications web, distribuées en mode SaaS et généralement propriétaires.

Les website builders du marché

Voici quelques statistiques concernant les acteurs propriétaires :

  • Godaddy, 3 500 employés, USA
  • Weebly, 600 employés, USA
  • Wix, 550 employés, Israel
  • Squarespace, 200 employés, USA

Ils ont donc ces caractéristiques en commun :

  • Enormément de templates
  • Commercial support
  • Integrated hosting and registrar
  • E-commerce
  • Ajout de fonctionnalités possibles à travers des APIs prévues à cet effet ou à de l'injection de code.

Le website builder libre Silex

Statistiques :

Silex, 0 employé, France

Philosophie :

  • do it yourself / comprendre ce qu'on fait
  • flexible, ultra pluggable
  • adapté au besoin de ceux qui participent à son développement
  • en constante évolution

Par exemple, dans Squarespace l'injection de code est une fonctionnalité avancée, alors que dans Silex, elle au coeur du processus de création d'un site.

Caractéristiques :

  • peu de templates, mais pensé pour Silexiser des templates HTML
  • Commercial support: embauchez des freelances de la communauté, des contributeurs
  • Integration de Dropbox, du FTP, Owncloud, webdav, Cozycloud, Github
  • Permet d'être hébergé par n'importe quel hébergeur, et en particulier par des hébergeurs associatifs comme toile libre.  

Des questions? Vous voulez savoir comment est financé l'hébergement? Quelle est la fréquentation / le nombre d'utilisateurs?
